segments.text: And again, we set up to stay behind ambush.
And we pulled this off three times in one morning.
And militarily, it was very successful.
And then the next day, we had pamphlets printed up how terrible the Viet Cong was.
We were trying to serve the people of the area for medical programs.
The only thing they wanted to do was kill us.
We had their interests in mind.
These pamphlets were printed up and dropped by aircraft over the area.
You can see how we used it, not only militarily, but propaganda-wise.
My medical program.
After the propaganda, was there any more trouble with this sort of thing?
Oh yes.
Another thing I did was that I could get free food and clothing often.

to strengthen the local government in the area was that for anybody to get the free food or clothing and things like this that they had to have a VFNE's ID card, which they had to register for and so on.
And for free food and clothing, because of

the requirement I set down and then I would have the local village chief or whoever handle the paperwork and check the people off and make sure they had the proper identification before they received any.
And this way I strengthened the local officials there.
And one trick that I did was that I could get T-shirts, children T-shirts that were basically red with three yellow stripes diagonally across it.
And a lot of the children, say, under seven, eight years old, didn't have a stitch of clothes on them.
And so I would, when I went into a village, I would give them these t-shirts, and that was the only clothes they had.
And of course, these were Viet Cong village.
But this was just like having a South Vietnamese flag.
And I'm sure there was a lot of family arguments later on over the t-shirts.
What were the major diseases of the Vietnamese that
Probably the most deadly was pneumonia.
But saw everything.
I even had at one time four cases of rabies.
Rabies, where did they pick that up from?
From a rabid dog.
And in fact when I heard about they brought in a child to me that was bitten by a rabid dog and of course I wanted to go out and see the dog.
And I went out there and the dog evidently followed them in the camp when they came into the camp.
And when I went out there he started to come towards me and normally
I always wore a .45 even on sick call and I had my .45 out and was about ready to blow it up and it died right in front of me and it was rabid.
How did you learn to, I know you had medical training and stuff so I'm sure that helped, but how did you learn to cope with death?

I guess part of our training was that way because we, at that time, at the advanced medical training lab, which was eight weeks long after we had approximately say over a year of training before that, if we got through that we went to

advanced medical lab and we had patients there and the patients were the dogs around Fayetteville that were going to be destroyed by the animal control anyway and what they would do they would shoot the dog in the hind leg with an M1 and of course this was done under very humane conditions the dog was asleep and everything and then we would perform surgery
on the dog to remove, to debris the dead tissue and so on.
And we had regular surgical teams like a surgeon, assistant surgeon, scrub nurse, anesthetist, and so on.
And after a debris month, we could not use any antibiotics to treat any infection, but we had to treat
the infection by cleaning it out four or five times a day.
And then we would go ahead and put the dog back under anesthetic and do a secondary closure and make sure that healed up good without any infection.
And then the last time we put it under anesthetic, we would do an amputation.
And after the amputation, we would actually kill the dog

with the anesthetic and since they were going to be destroyed anyway and if your patient did not survive, died on you, you had to do an autopsy on the patient and then you got a new one and you started all over again.
So there was a lot of sleepless nights taking care of your patient during the training and
I think on the whole that they trained us for deaf because I can remember in some of the classes that in my final training, which was a 13 week training period, that two of the main instructors
would inform us almost every day of who died over in Vietnam, and I can remember it was getting up to over 350.
They would number them, and generally, probably nine percent of them were Special Forces, and they would know the people, and they would tell us something about the people.
So we were very, we knew that where we were going was not
an easy place to stay alive.
Did you find that American technology was very useful to medics?
Oh yes, because the local medicine around there, they were using like suction cups and bleeding the patients and things like this.
And they had their local
which doctors or whatever you want to call them that they did a treatment.
What was the strengths and weaknesses that you saw in the American forces in caring for the wounded?
Well, of course Americans normally could get evacuated out of the valley area when they were wounded very rapidly to a

a field hospital and be taken, have very good care taken of them and with very well trained personnel and evacuated from there back to the United States or to like Okinawa, Japan very fast, which was full-fledged hospitals and was excellent.
How were they evacuated usually?
By trucks or by helicopters?
By choppers.
What were some weaknesses or were there any that you could have seen been improved?
Well, as far as my unit was, we were sort of stuck out there in nowhere and the only time we could get air support
was when we had an American hit or his life was in danger of being there.
And only one time that happened was when one of my teammates was killed, that we got air support.
Other than that, we had no air support whatsoever.
What about the availability of blood?
Because that would seem like it would be a vital supply.
I had none.
But I did have gem garbium, which is a form of plasma, but concentrated.
As far as it went on the VF knees, that 50 cc's of gamgobium IV was just like a unit of blood.
How was this usually transported to you?
It was regular cans and IV bottles.
I generally carried at least two of them around with me every time I went on patrol.
What were the other supplies that you carried with you in your medical kit?
Well, basic bandages and wire splints and things like this.
It all depended on the patrol.
If I was going out to set up a medical treatment someplace, of course I carried much larger supplies and so on to treat with the idea of treating
anywhere from 50 to maybe 200 or 300 people that day, which I had to take a whole range of medications and antibiotics and other things such as that.
Was there ever any problem with the supplies running low?
Sometimes.
Probably the most used medication I had was antibiotics.
And I would say, if I ever ran out, of course I always figured on a large supply ahead and was really planning on it, and I kept a large supply at the camp.
When the supplies would run low,
And if y'all were like invaded, were there ever, you know, did your priorities as far as who to treat and how to treat, did they change as a result of the shortage in supplies at all?
No, but we did have some supplies that were for Americans only.
And, uh, uh, and, uh, uh,
Basically, it was very rare that I had to not treat someone with a secondary medication than the preferred medication.
I guess I'd like to shift gears just a little bit and talk a little bit
about you as far as your experiences.
How were you injured?
What were the conditions?
Well, it was not very dramatic.
It wasn't any big battle.
We had a big operation going that day and planned out the

conventional pincher action that we would send one unit well we had one unit going north one south and then they swing around and then we would have a major unit go west as a sweep and try to get caught between the higher two units and a crossfire and I was on a unit that went north which we left you know about

three or four hours early so we could make a wide circle so they wouldn't know what was coming and tried to do it that way and while we were making these wide sweeps we would call in our position and the mortars were trained from the camp in other words they walked in front of us
In case we ran into an ambush, the only thing we had to do was hit the radio and say, fire.
And the mortars would be firing, you know, 100, 200 yards in front of us at all times.
And what happened was I was taking a compass reading, and a booby trap grenade went off where I was standing, right under my feet.
And that's how I was injured.
In fact, my team sergeant claimed that he stepped on the grenade before I did and probably primed it.
And so when I was standing on and taking the compass reading, it exploded.
And one unusual thing was that this was, I was going on my 11th month in Vietnam, and
was the only day that I knew that I was going to be a casualty.
I told my CO at the time that that day was my day.
Was it just intuition?
Sixth Sense.
What was the extent of the injury?
The only external injury was I picked up shrapnel wounds in my left foot and ankle and with broken bones in my left foot.
My right foot was completely broken up and no external injuries but the concussion, I probably, I was standing on, it went off under my right foot and so it got most of the concussion.

which led to rupture of all the blood vessels and therefore the foot did not get any blood circulation so what they called dry gangrene and seven days later they had to amputate it because it was just a dead piece of meat.
What were your immediate thoughts?
Since you had kind of sensed it, what went through your mind as the injury occurred?
Well, it wasn't until later that I remembered that I knew it was going to happen.
The unit I was with that went on and left me there with two Vietnamese soldiers and

I was only about a hundred yards from the Cambodian border, which was somewhat dangerous, and I knew that if the Viet Cong found me there, the two Viet Minh soldiers would have hightailed it and left me there.
So my main concern was preparing myself to fight to the death.
immediate hospital care like in Vietnam?
I can't really say because after I got to Saigon and put in the hospital, they gave me a shot and knocked me out.
I can't really remember anything until approximately two or three weeks later because I went in a coma because I had blood clots that moved up to my brain and I received
30% brain damage from the bug spots.
When you were coming back to the United States, what was the emotions like coming back on the trip back?
I just wanted to get back to the States.
I know
When I finally got back to the States about three weeks later, when they went into Travis Air Force Base, I just wanted to kiss the ground when I got back here.
What was the date that you arrived back?
I can't remember.
When you got back, you said you were at Travis.
How long were you at Travis?
Just overnight.
And then I flew into here in San Antonio to Brook Army Medical Center and I spent two and a half years there being put back together.
What was your relations with the hospital staff like at Brooks?
Very good.
Were there any
problems that you had with them at all?

A few of them with the nurses, but after I was able to get up and get around, most of the doctors found out of my medical training, and when they went around to do bandage changes on most of the other patients, they preferred me to.
work with them because my knowledge of how to do bandage changes was probably greater than the nurses were there.
The nurses resented this quite a bit, but that was all right.
You got to realize I was wounded
in September of 65, and my enlistment was up in November of 65.
So after a year in the hospital, you know, my enlistment was already a year past.
And if I wanted a three-day pass, I just would tell the doctor I wanted a three-day pass.
And he said, no, I can't give you one.
I said, okay, don't look for me.
Monday or Friday I'd take off and when I got back they had the three day pass for me assigned.
So they were very cooperative.
Well, what could they do?
I've read where there's been problems as far as for Vietnam veterans in the hospitals.
Some of the major problems were like age gap because I know I can
I'm not sure, but it seemed like the Vietnam veterans were much younger than most of the other veterans in the hospital.
This is only, I would say, to the VA hospital.
When I was initially wounded in the Army hospitals, it was mostly from Vietnam.
Although there was some soldiers there,
that was their third war.
But yet there was camaraderie.
Of course there was different things.
The Marines thought they were
And of course the special forces thought they were too.
The Air Force always got the low end of the stick.
It was the normal thing.
You got to realize that after I was there, when I got there in the hospital there was only six amputees and three of us was from Vietnam and three of us from car accidents.

and by the year's time it grew up to almost a hundred amputees there in the hospital and they had to open up a whole ward that they were saving for national disaster for it and make it just a purely amputee ward.
But there was some racial
problems, of course, but nothing great.
In the VA, was there ever any, did you ever find any lack of communication between, say, the doctors and the patients?
Yes.
Most of your VA hospitals you'll find are next to medical centers or medical
schools.
And you get a lot of students over there, maybe second and third year medical students playing doctor.
And like I am, by the time I go, when I need to go to the VA hospital for something, I don't even know what it is and what needs to be done and so on.
And sometimes I have run runs with the young
kids and most of them don't like to be told what to do.
But on the whole I've gotten into most of the doctors I see most of the time are the ones I choose.
I work around and get that way, which most patients don't know how to do.
How do you go about doing this?
Well, I do homework first.
If I don't like somebody, I just tell them that, and I wish to see somebody else.
If I have to do that three or four times, I do until I get somebody I have confidence in, and then I go with them.
It's that easy.
I think your medical...
training has helped quite a bit too.
Yes.
Now a lot of people they don't realize that just recently this Freedom of Information Act also applies to all hospitals and even the civilians.
If a civilian wants to know in a civilian hospital why he's being treated for and the medications
and how much medication and so on and what side effects, the hospital has to tell you.
And if you want your records from that hospital, they have to provide them for you.
And a lot of people don't know this, but you can get real stiff about and you get done.
In fact, this last summer when I was up in Oregon with my mother with an accident, I really put a few nurses through the wringer that they thought they could slough me off.
In fact, some doctors also did that.
They would say, well, it's the administration.
I would say,
Well, what do you mean by administration?
Well, the Board of Review.
What's the Board of Review?
Well, I said, where the patient can pay or not, right?
And they said, yes.
And I said, well, you don't have to worry about that.
That's my worry.
And get things taken care of that way.
And sometimes I got pretty pushy, but I got things done.
Yeah.
Have you ever run across any dishonesty
in the VA, or as far as, like, the nurses saying things, as far as, like, treatment or something like that?
Well, the VA system is a whole different ballgame.
And, of course, my major concern with the VA system is this Agent Orange.
And the VA has cut and dried
that's put out by Washington, the head Veterans Administration Office, what the VA does.
And the personnel who work for the VA can't else, have to follow those instructions, and they're very limited.
And if, I know when I went in for my initial interview about Agent Orange,
They called in the security, because if I was getting a little too forceful, I'd tell them what's what.
But I got my point across.
And it really irked me that a nurse did the interview and not a doctor.
How do you feel about the medical services being circumscribed according to criteria
unrelated to medical needs.
They don't look at your injuries or your treatments that you need.
They look at other things into consideration.
Well, of course money is one of the major things.
If the VA hospital here was twice the size, it still would be filled, I believe.
I honestly believe that.
And why it's so terrible about it is that they don't have it.
And then the other thing is the veteran is ill-informed of what his rights are.
Because when they put it out, they either put it out in a language that a normal person cannot understand, or they put only half-truths out.
While you were recuperating back at Travis, were you expected to maintain a military appearance with the haircut?
Well, at Travis I only spent overnight.
Oh.
But at Brooke, yes, you were.
I had no problem with that whatsoever because I believe in it and there was no difficulty.
Probably the biggest problem was a lack of medical help
From doctors on down, as you went down, it got less and less.
In fact, there on the amputee ward, they wanted amputees to mop and buff the floors and things like this.
And the nurses was always telling me to do this and do that about that.
I would tell them, well, heck, I'm an NCO.
You give me some war-ranked people and I would be
supervisor of the detail.
They never could get a detail up, so I never supervised anything.
I bet they loved you.
Oh, they did.
What was the morale like back at Brooks?
It depended on

unit and normally you'll find somebody with severe injuries such as amputation or anything like that if the person has the will to survive and to do what he wants to do even though with handicaps that they will do it but if they don't they become a
there's a big difference between being handicapped and being a cripple.
And most of the people who are cripples are because of their mental outlook on it.
They say, okay, I'm a cripple, I will be a cripple.
Not that what I can do, I will do.
And this goes for the whole spectrum.
Either I believe that either you grew up
with the thought that, with the will to overcome hardships or you don't have it.
And I think that's ingrained in your younger years and you follow through with it in your later years.
How did y'all, you know, like if a guy was a cripple, how did, was there any way that you
that the other patients would try to help him to get his morale up to show him that he could still be productive?
Oh, yeah.
I know when I was there, I had, there was a guy that had a train went over his legs and he lost both his legs.
And filling out the menu, which you would, the food was very good at Brooks, and you filled out your own menu, what you wanted to select from
And he was always asking me for my pen or pencil.
I just, you know, after about the second day, I told him to get his own and keep it.
And then I didn't let him use mine anymore.
I would do or die.
If he didn't want to fill out his menu, that was his problem.
And I remember one guy, he got hit up on our guy, and our guy with both his legs gone right up the hip, he was asking for help.
And our guy looked up at him and said, what do you think you are, cripple or something?
And it's a lot different when you have a large group of severely injured people
together because you can always look around and find somebody worse off than you are.
It seems like y'all helped each other more than anybody else could.
Oh yeah.
Just by forcing each other to do things.
That's just like in college when you get a rough instructor if you group together
I had to work out the problems how to pass the course.
It's a lot easier doing it by yourself.
Yeah, I found that true in this one history class that I just had.
Did you find that, back at Brooks, that being a Vietnam veteran made a difference in your relations with the hospital staff?
No.
If anything, we were preference.
Being combat wounded could be preference over value, but not very obvious.
As far as your rehabilitation programs,
Did you ever have any encounter group programs?
Initially, no.
I know one thing that like when I found out that there were going to have fireworks were out Beach Pavilion where a lot of the people were and
It was right next to the parade field, and twice a year they would have fireworks out there on the parade field.
And I kept telling the staff that, you know, be sure to tell everybody there's going to be fireworks, because look out.
And the first couple times they sloughed it off, and there was some real messes.
Because the guy on the
first fireworks go off and boy the first thing they do is get under their bed and it didn't matter whether they were in tractions or what.
And there was some injuries caused from it and I don't know why they kept the fireworks right there, right next to Maine Hospital, but they did.
Did you have very much contact with veterans of other wars that hadn't been in Vietnam?
No, not a lot.
Did, in your relations with veterans who have been through other wars, do you find that the Vietnam veterans had a different view of the military?
Well, the normal, I say grunt, which means normal infantry or whatever, they
Roy did because they thought it was a useless war and they were always thrown into it.
When I was a voluntarily enlisted and I felt like I was doing good in Vietnam and I was serving a purpose and most of the soldiers did not feel this way.
So I'm sort of oddball in that respect.
How does the presence of, like in the VA, the presence of veterans from other wars, how do they affect you?
Well, I wouldn't say that was a problem, but the problem is that the VA handles all veterans, whether they were in a war or not.
And you take someone, well I knew there at Brooke we had this one guy and wasn't anything wrong.
What happened was he got drunk in France and climbed a power pole and touched a hot wire and burned both his hands off.
And when he
got out of the military.
He got no military retirement whatsoever, but he was 100% disabled by the Veterans Administration.
I'm only 80% disabled by the Veterans Administration, and he has a lot more privileges than I do.
It falls under the category, the first category that they have is service-connected or non-service-connected.
His was non-service-connected, but yet he has more benefits than I do.
And this I find fault with.
And there's a lot of people in the VA hospital
are non-service connected.
And service connected means where you are injured in the line of duty or not, which can become quite touchy.
What about veterans who receive the benefit, but who in reality really are not disabled?
People such as General Curtis LeMay, who
claimed to be disabled, but yet he still went on to get his pilot's license and flies privately and was also a prospect for vice presidential candidate.
What is your feelings about that?
It's a way that a lot of people get out paying extra income tax.
It's a loophole in the income tax system which causes this.
Unless it has nothing to do really with VA then.
Oh, yes.
Because if the VA finds him disabled, say 30% disabled, then 30% of his retirement pay is non-taxable.
So what can I say about that?
Do you think that's the fault of the Internal Revenue Service or the fault of the VA?
I don't know where the fault lies, but if, say, he was 30% disabled, then cause in line of duty and so on, I think then he deserves it.
But lots of times when, say, a general goes in for an examination like that, he gets this because he's a general.
And rank has its privileges.
While you were recuperating at Brooks, did you ever have very much exposure to the outside world as far as like passes and things?
Oh yes.
Was there no difficulty there?
Normally not.
Two or three times I got a thirty day convalescent leave.
and sometimes I went home or just flew all over the country or whatever.
And surprising as it may seem, almost every place I went I was, because to fly a military standby you have to do it in uniform, and I was well received by all the
The only place that I wasn't well received was at Colorado Springs, Colorado.
And probably that was because there were so many people there that were head to Vietnam that they didn't know how to take me.
And when I was there I was on crutches without my prosthesis.
Yeah, Green Belay, they didn't know, boy, how to take it.
It's a little bit more personal.
Do you remember what your parents' reactions were the first time they saw you after your injury?
No, not really.
Part of my injuries was I had complete amnesia and when I woke up in the hospital there at Clark Air Force Base, I didn't even know my own name.

And I was not a good patient there because they were speaking basically Spanish there because it was in the Philippines and I got that confused with my Vietnamese if I was a prisoner of war in North Vietnam.
The only thing I wanted to do was escape, and I was not a good patient.
As far as your treatment went, what kind of medication did they have you on?
Basically the only medication I was on was some mild painkillers as Aspirin as I needed unless I was in surgery or something and then I got heavy.
